title: Did Jimi Hendrix know chords? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Jimi Hendrix knew chords. He even had a signature chord, the dom7#9 chord, which he didn’t invent but which became the thing that you play if you want to instantly sound like Hendrix. I analyse it here: Alex Johnston's answer to How did Jimi Hendrix develop the Hendrix chord? Hendrix’s knowledge of harmony was far in advance of that of his guitar player peers in England—at least, when he arrived there. Blues players like Eric Clapton and Peter Green had focused on single-string melodic playing. Jeff Beck had a somewhat more harmonically sophisticated approach thanks to his teenage love of players like Les Paul, Cliff Gallup and Steve Cropper. Jimmy Page was steeped in folk, and Pete Townshend had developed the power chord. But none of them had had an apprenticeship like Hendrix’s years on the road as a guitarist with soul and R&B groups. When Hendrix got to England, he soaked up the music around him. The stately, extensive chordal introduction to ‘Little Wing’ is developed from the chordal playing of guitarists like Bobby Womack and Curtis Mayfield, and Hendrix adds a dash of English folk music and even a touch of classical music. I’ve analysed this too: Alex Johnston's answer to Why have some people called the introduction to "Little Wing" by Jimi Hendrix pure genius? Hendrix knew chords so well that he doesn’t seem to have regarded chords and melody as being distinct from each other. His solos on his version of Bob Dylan’s ‘All Along the Watchtower’ are worth studying in this respect.  Don’t even get me started on the rhythmic sophistication of the introduction. My college music theory teacher analysed it for us once and I still don’t understand it. The first solo break comes in 0:53, and it’s a single melodic line in the minor pentatonic scale. But listen to Hendrix’s licks during the verses: he regularly alternates the tonic and flattened seventh with the perfect fourth and minor third, sometimes playing them as double-stops, as he does at 1:34. The second solo break is at 1:43. This time it’s in the natural minor, with Hendrix making much use of seconds and ninths, but at 2:00 Hendrix starts playing slide in octaves, allowing other notes to come in and out. At 2:16 he starts using the wah-wah and heavy tape echo, and this time the rapid changes in timbre and the echo effect mean that the notes he just played are often still sounding as he plays the succeeding ones, creating an effect of him harmonising with himself. Then, at 2:33, he breaks into full chordal playing, including chord substitution at 2:36–2:37. This is typical of Hendrix: when one technique no longer suffices for him to say what he wants to say, he uses another from his vast arsenal. ‘All Along the Watchtower’ was constructed using many, many overdubs. According to engineer Tony Bongiovi, Hendrix was constantly dissatisfied and erased many tracks: as his conception of the song expanded, they went from using a four-track tape machine to a twelve-track and eventually a 16-track. But when Hendrix didn’t use overdubs, his mastery of chordal playing meant that he could play rhythm and lead simultaneously, as he did in ‘Voodoo Child (Slight Return)’.  Listen to the phrase Hendrix plays at 2:16, and how he develops it. It starts as a standard blues lick, Hendrix bending from the fourth to the fifth on one string and alternating it with the seventh on the next string up, but as he leans into his wah-wah pedal and rocks it quickly, the phrase gets smeared over the course of the next few seconds into an increasingly desperate, increasingly distorted, and slowly sinking set of variations on the minor third, flattened fifth and seventh, before leaping up at 2:25 to a screaming high B. That’s a guitarist who is no longer thinking in terms of chords and melodies as being separate things from each other. He’s playing and thinking in terms of several musical things going on at once. So, yes, Hendrix knew chords. He knew them so well that, as other answers to this question have suggested, he transcended them.

upvoters.user_id: Isaiah Howansky (イザヤホワンスキー）

response.answer_text: Yes. Yes, he did. We’re talking about someone who likely spent around 14 hours a day playing a guitar. A person who almost always had a guitar within arm’s reach. It might be tempting to listen to all those other-worldly, psychadelic solos he played and think “who needs chords?! He didn’t!” Except that he played chords, too. Lots of them. He was so fluid at transitioning from rhythm chords to lead lines that if you’re not paying attention you might not notice, or you might be tempted to think it was another guitarist. But, no. It was him. He played lots of chords. He was thoroughly familiar with the fretboard and the possibilities for combining fretted and unfretted strings in almost uncountable variations. If it was a possible combination (in terms of could-his-fingers-make-it-happen), chances are good that he tried it - and if it sounded good, he used it. If you’ve ever heard the song “Purple Haze” (and if you haven’t, go listen to it. Now.), there’s a particular sound in it, a sound the song is more or less built around. It’s a chord. To be specific, it’s an E7#9. I mention this chord because it’s commonly referred to as “the Hendrix chord.” No, he didn’t “invent” it - but he definitely popularized it, even if non-musicians didn’t know what they were hearing. Beyond the fact that he’s got a signature chord named after him, listen to the intro to “Little Wing.” Really. Go listen to it now. The intro is a beautiful combination of picked single strings along with gorgeous double- and triple-stops. It’s the double- and triple-stops I want to point out, because what they show is that he was familiar enough not just with the chords as whole units but with the components of the chords that he knew what he needed and what he didn’t. He knew that what you don’t play is as important as what you do play. That intro is minimalism in action, and it’s wonderful. Those aren’t combinations he stumbled upon randomly. He knew chords well enough to know how to make the sounds he wanted.  (image found via Google Images search)

Does the Pope know the 10 commandments? Yes - Jimi Hendrix knew chords. He knew sounds. I doubt that he ever studied music theory but he knew how various tones worked together. One thing that you will find if you look at the photos and videos of Jimi playing is that you will very rarely (and as far as I have seen ever) see him play a barre chord. He had large hands and liked to wrap his thumb around the guitar neck to fret the 5th and 6ths strings. Jimi liked to chop up chords and often would strike 2 or three strings at a time to give the flavor of a chord while he worked his magic on the other strings. He was also a very percussive player and used the deaden strings to add percussion effects to his playing. They’ll be studying what Hendrix did with the electric guitar 100 years from now, just like we are talking about 49 years after his passing.

Jimi Hendrix knew chords VERY WELL. Much better than many other players like Keith Richards (just as an example). He uses very exotic chords and chord progressions and it is very clear if you listen to a few of his pieces like Valleys of Neptune, Third Stone from the Sun, etc. Even his solos are “chord based” meaning that he takes the hint of the chord he’s on to start a melody or a solo with his guitar (like in the intro of Castles Made of Sand or the solo on Bold as Love).

Ha! Is this a serious question? You’re wondering whether one of the greatest guitarists who ever lived knew chords? The answer is yes. Who did you think was playing the chords on Jimi Hendrix records? Perhaps you’re wondering something like whether Jimi knew the names of the chords he was playing? The answer is also “yes”. Sorry, I’m just a bit flabbergasted at this question.
Does it matter if he new chords, he was the best, andif he didnt, he was laughing all the way to the bank, of course he knew chords
